title: Alcatraz, San Francisco
address: Bay Street and Embarcadero, Pier 33 Alcatraz Landing, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
The ferry ride out was pretty quick. I like the timed tickets. The island and prison itself is really neat. The audio tour was very in depth to the point of being a bit too long. The views are great.

So easy to get to the famous Rock. Just follow the piers to No. 33. It's the only way to visit Alcatraz. Run by the US Nat Parks. About US$30 gets you ferry and tour including the audio headsets (a must do) Fantastic views of the Bay and Bridges are a bonus

The tour takes approximately two/three hours. Ordering the tickets online and collecting on the day was easy and pain free.
The whole experience was well organised with minimal waiting in lines.
You are free to roam around Alcatraz on your own should you wish and there's some amazing views of the city from the island which is worth the trip...


More  



The experience was amazing, very informative (something my inner history geek loved) and yet the audio tour allows you to avoid the annoyance of having to follow a group and a tour guide everywhere, only listening to have of what they say. The organization of the cruise system is great, we were late and they squeezed us in a later...


More  



Taking the boat ride over to the island builds you anticipation to walk through the prison. You are otfitted with a set of earphones which walks you through the old prison and you hear prison sounds on your walk, very authentic.

Did a night-time tour of Alcatraz and it was amazing and eerie at the same time. The views from the prison are spectacular but a somber mood is felt when a recollection of the harsh conditions is made. Book at least 1 month in advanced because tickets sell out really quickly. This place will fail to disappoint!

A must see! It is kind of surreal to be where all those prisoners were kept, but very interesting tour. Definitely do the audio tour of the cell house. Very smooth run operation.

This is the 2nd time I have been there .Love it. The audio tour is well designed, easy to understand and very informative. You can spend as long as you want there. We had a bonus that an ex prisoner was there signing his book and happy to chat to you. Makes the visit even more real. Upkeep and maintenance...


More  



We took the Alcatraz tour many years ago when they first opened it up for public viewing. Do not miss a trip to Alcatraz if you are in San Francisco. We were just in San Francisco again and it brought back fond memories of our long ago trip. It is something you will never forget.

Even if you have no interest in history I'm sure people of all ages will enjoy this. The trip to and from the island is short and not too costly. You can order the tickets a week or two in advance to make things easier. I try to go later in the day so there's not as much fog around...


More

title: Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco
address: Lincoln Boulevard, near Doyle Drive and Fort Point, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
There is plenty of parking on the city side of the bridge. Just park and walk as far as you want to. The Sausalito side also has parking but it was closed when we were there in late January. It is good to drive over the bridge, go down to the park below and view it before returning and parking...


More  



We took a bus to see the bridge, took our pictures in front of the bridge and then took a walk on the bridge. Get up close to view this marvel.

There's no other way to experience the awe than on foot or possibly driving through the mountains to hawks point. So glad my wife and I went!

Nice place to walk, especially for people who like physical activity. We took a walk after few hours on Hop-On, Hop-Off bus and liked it very much. There are restrooms on both sides of the bridge. Don't forget to bring camera and walking shoes.

beautiful view on a beautiful day. What an engineering marvel and work of art. Great photo ops from both ends of the span.

We walked the bridge, and it was totally worth it, The weather was amazing, and all the people were either out for a stroll or bike ride. We stopped and clicked many pictures on the way. If you are making a trip to San Francisco, it will be incomplete without a stop at Golden Gate Bridge.

Hire a bike and cycle over the bridge. There is a dedicated cycle lane for the length of the bridge. Great views all along the bridge on either side, particularly over the Pacific Ocean in the afternoon once the sun is being to dip.

It's an icon for San Francisco and the Bay Area. On the north ( Marin) side there are parking lots to get out and talk and take pictures. The east side sidewalk is mixed use. Both bike riders and walkers/runners can use it. Be cautions of bike riders as some areas are narrow around the towers. If your driving, be...


More  



It has always been my dream to travel over the bridge and I must say that it far exceeded my expectations. We took one of the open bus tours so the ride was thrilling to say the least. The views overlooking the bay was breathtakingly beautiful and to see the architectural brilliance of the bridge up front and personal was...


More  



Walk it, bike it, drive it, do whatever you can. It's worth it. Not only is the bridge a monumentally graceful piece of architecture but it is such an imposing juxtaposition of steel against earth and rock and sky. Visually amazing!

title: San Francisco Bay, San Francisco
review_list:
My friend and I went to see the nightview of Golden Bridge in the evening. It was great to ride a bike at night. You will not get much sun burn and the wind is great.
However, it was not a good time to take photos at night. And there are special time schedules for cycling lanes on the Golden...


More  



A truly fascinating icon of a bridge. Have visited and taken photos of this bridge from almost every angle available. Love this monster of a bridge.

A must see when visiting San Francisco. I would suggest walking or biking the bridge. You need to pay a toll so be prepared since they don't take cash.

It is one of the most beautiful bays in the world. one can admire it from the Russian Hill or the different points around the bay, even through both bridges.

Its a history in itself. Go and stand there in the middle and then looking at an island you find the Alcatraz prison. I could recall the TV series Break out based on this prison. The vastness amuses every sense.

We visited San Francisco and did a cruise around the bay and also viewed it from the Golden Gate Bridge. The bay area is great viewing from Fishermans wharf also, and has lots of seals that Lounge about on the pontoons. Taking a cruise around the bay is a great way to get close to alcatraz and see the bridge...


More  



Just loved this place. You can see Alcatraz from here or take a ferry out there. Grab a bowl of clam chowder in a bread bowl and just sit and watch the boats go by. There is transportation right down to the bay on the San Fran trollies. It's a super place for photo fanatics. Most relaxing and not to...


More  



I left my Heart in San Francisco, truly did. I'm not sure if it was because of the point in time that I went or if the city just stole my heart. Loved it there, something about it that was serene and comforting and enjoyable. Will definitely go again. I walked every where, I was under a very tight budget,...


More  



I been there at windy day, so cold but nice view and beautiful Bay.
I will be back very soon and discovery more

Totally love the area, but the traffic is a huge problem. We planning to visit Point Reyes, from Oakland, on a Saturday morning, but the traffic turned a 45 mile ride into over 3 hours!! Totally changed the plans!!

title: AT&T Park, San Francisco
address: 24 Willie Mays Plaza, San Francisco, CA 94103
review_list:
A real American baseball stadium. Big, with many options to suit your price range. Food and drinks available, try the garlic fries they're awesome. Ask about access to your seat, access is sometimes difficult with a place this size, so if you have sore feet or legs you'll want to use the elevators, in which case you should get there...


More  



My husband has seen many games here and loves it! We visited recently to take a tour. We got to go on the field, into a luxury suite, in the dugout, and even in the visiting team's locker room. A lot of fun for a small amount of money.

I really like this park. AT&T Park has plenty to see they have the cable car they have the slide for the kids. They also have really good food lots of variety you must try the garlic fries when you go there.

I loved that people were hanging out on the bay on rafts and inflatable boats watching the game. Great views from any seat, worth checking out.

We love our trips to San Francisco, especially when we are lucky enough to catch a Giants game at AT&T Park. Parking in the area is never a problem. The park is incredibly clean; staff is always friendly and helpful; and food stands are plenty!

What a view,in the stadium as well as around it,clear ocean,blue skies,vast expanse of humanity swaying to history being made!
A ball game becomes a fond memory because of its historic significance.Home to so many famous events,it a worthy landmark and one feels privileged to have witnessed a game here.It is a magnificent edifice ,located on the marina and no...


More  



The setting, right on the bay, is spectacular. And it's the Giants!
But wait, there's more: did I mention the amazing food and drink available here? I know people who come here for the food first, then a game if they're not too busy chowing down. Epic beers! Great wines!
They play baseball here, too. It's all good!
Enjoy!

Although I am no Giants fan, this place is very nice. Seating and the views are great and it's right on the water. Transit station right outside makes it easy to get to and plenty of eating establishments close by. The Embarcadaro is right down the street

I love this place, to me it feels like a cathedral. My last memories of AT&T is when MadBum pitched a freakish game in game 5 of the World Series. I can't wait to get back there to smash some hot dogs and a few beers. Go Giants - even year magic.

Of course I'm partial being a Giants fan but this is truly one of the prettier ball fields around. A great view of the bay, the field is beautiful to look at and it just feels like baseball.

title: Golden Gate Park, San Francisco
review_list:
Stroll and view the beauty of the park on a Sunday afternoon! There are dance lessons, roller skating, food carts, and lots happening! Museums are open, but we didn't visit because the weather was so glorious that we enjoyed the sunny day instead!

Golden Gate Park grew out of sand dunes into a 1017 acre green oasis. Next time I go, I will rent a bike to see the botanical gardens and the Japanese tea garden. This trip we took the free park shuttle that runs every 15 minutes, but missed seeing a lot of the park.

Plenty of space for people to enjoy literally any type of outdoor activity - organized sport, BBQs, yoga or just a picnic, Golden Gate Park is the gem of San Francisco. Don't miss out on a beautiful Saturday afternoon in the park.

My husband and I spent Valentine's Day here. We were lucky to have good weather, but besides that we loved the variety of attractions! Museums, food, hiking, botanical gardens, and so much more! I would highly recommend slotting at least half of a day here.

Most major, top tier cities have some number of beautiful parks and recreation areas for the public to enjoy, but Golden Gate Park would have to be at or near the top of anyone's list. The park is absolutely immense, and extremely well kept, clean and cared for. It has numerous sections well spread out from each other ranging from...


More  



This park has something for everyone. Parking your car on MLK Drive is good for 4 hours, if you arrive early am. I personally take the muni, and with a short walk get to the De Young Museum, which offers art from all over the world. If you are there during May, it's an easy walk to the beautiful Rose...


More  



This Park rivals Central Park. Lots of activities and things to see and do. Loved the Japanese Tea garden. I wished the windmills actually worked. Let via haight ashbury and that was a another experience.

Lying in the center of one of North America's most beautiful cities, Golden Gate Park offers multiple
Entertainments for people of all ages. Highlights include the Deyoung Museum of American Art and its observation tower, The California Academy of Sciences and Steinhart Aquarium with its Exceptional educational exhibits and albino alligator, the heard of American Bison, the House of Flowers...


More  



If you're traveling as a family with little ones, this is the place to go to! So spacious and with many things to do! Parents don't need to worry kids being loud or anything. They'll just run around and be ready to hit the hay once back to the hotel. (Yay!) We went to the Japanese Tea Garden and really...


More  



I visited the park on a cloudy day by myself, and while the weather could've been nicer it was still lovely! With numerous attractions within the park, there was something for everyone. I loved the Botanical Gardens and Japanese Gardens (both cost $8).
I walked from one end to the other which took just over 2 hours. I would recommend...


More

title: Lands End, San Francisco
address: Point Lobos Avenue and El Camino del Mar, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
This is the ultimate experience for anyone wanting to see and explore San Francisco's breathtaking, magnificent coast. This walk is a must for all visitors, whether first timers or returning pilgrims. The views from Lands End are gorgeous, stupendous and unforgettable. Allow plenty of time and don't rush it. Stop along the way and savor the fresh air, ocean, rocks...


More  



This is one of favorite place to hike. The view is breath taking. I could wonder around here all day.

Arrived in town around noon on a Sunday and decided to take the 38R to the end of the line. Surf was up and the views were spectacular. Lots of people out for a Sunday outing, so there was a festive air. Nice trail network, with great views of the GG Bridge as you go north and east. Good eats...


More  



If you're looking for an easy hike (more of a stroll really) with amazing views while in the San Francisco area, I highly recommend Lands End. The views of the ocean and Golden Gate are stunning. We recently went on President's Day. It was quite crowded but the weather was perfect. I'm sure it's much less crowded during the week.

I've hiked Land's End several times and each time it's different thanks to the changes in weather. It's stunning on a clear day - great views of the bay and the GG bridge - and nicely spooky in the fog.

A beautiful place for hiking. Not a very difficult hike, but the views are amazing. You can see the golden gate bridge, waves crashing against the rocks, and the interesting rock formations. If you are really adventurous, you can go off the trails and walk along the coast, but beware of big waves that might knock you over!

I've been to San Francisco many times, but this was the first time to Land's End. It's a great place to 1) hit the beach; 2) go hiking along the ocean trail; and/or 3) just sit back and enjoy the scenery - especially at sunset. It does get crowded on weekends so try to avoid that if possible. We rented...


More  



A lovely hiking destination. Not too many hills, but just enough to make your heart pump. Nice dirt trail with benches to stop for a packed lunch with a priceless view.

Love it here, Try to go on a weekday as its getting crowded on weekends. I have been going on a regular basis for 20+ years and its getting to manicured. Still beautiful. Park at the Clffi house and walk to the end and back. Take the stairs to the beach mid way. very wild feeling.

My cousin took me here to show me some of his favorite spots in San Francisco, and it won me over. There isn't a whole lot in the area besides a few restaurants but you don't really need much to go hiking/walking through the trails and to snap a couple pictures of the scenery. Plus in the distance you'll get...

title: Twin Peaks, San Francisco
address: 501 Twin Peaks Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94114
review_list:
If you want to get a sweeping view of the entire city, bay, and surrounding area from a lofty height, then Twin Peaks will give you that breathtaking view and perfect photo op. Just take care and don't leave anything of value in your car, as break-ins have become too common and pose a real challenge for local law enforcement.

Twin Peaks is a really nice spot to see the city at a hole. Just make sure you get there with enough time because there are a bunch of tour buses and sometimes there's no parking spots so you have to be patient to get a parking spot. There's no services up there as far as food so if you...


More  



This is great place to get a panoramic view of the city. Awesome view point and photo opportunity. It's a bit touristy, but you'll still be able to do what you need to...enjoy nod snap a few shots. It's also the home of one of those self cleaning toilets. I didn't give it a go....but maybe you want to!

From the viewpoint at Twin Peaks one can see all of San Francisco. Breathtaknig. One warning--don't go up there in the summer. You can barry see your hand in front of your face. Seemsw strange to have all that fog non the summer.

If you enjoy looking at the city from high above the rooftops, this is for sure your best bet. A sight seeing tour will get you here as well as renting a car but parking can be a little tricky if it's a perfect day so mind that. At the summit you get nice pictures of the city or of...


More  



For THE panoramic view of San Francisco. It was a clear day and we could see the entire city. I was told afterwards there has been reported robberies there but we didn't encounter anything suspicious.

Great spot to view the city. Passed by on a clear night to check the view. Definitely worth checking out when you are in San fransisco!

The ground is covered with green with small yellow flowers. We're lucky there's no cloud in the sky. Access is a little bit complicated and we took small tour bus to get there.

Great view. You can see the CBD and the Golden Bridge at the top.
It would be much more windy than in the city. So get something to keep warm.
Limited parking lots. But there are not many tourists on weekdays.
You can choose to drive or to hike to the top of the hills.
Recommended staying time: 30-45 min.

I found the peaks about 3 years ago. I've visited San Francisco nearly 100 times throughout my life. Amazing views. The only down side may be the fog. I have arrived and it has been wonderfully clear and in 10 minutes the fog roles in and we could see nearly nothing. It is truly a great place to get a...

title: The Exploratorium, San Francisco
address: Pier 15, on the Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
A lot of things to do. This place and the activities are suitable for all ages. The best time is Thursday night because of special rate for tickets $15 instead of $29. Also that time is happy hours. You can spend two-three hours there. Also there is restaurant on premises with good food, bar and tasty tea.

Best venue for kids for "hands on" experience with a range of scientific and artistic exhibits. We've lived in multiple cities / urban areas across the US, and this is the best for kid-friendly exhibits ! For families a "#1 Must Do".

I used to take my daughter and her friends here when it was at the Palace of Fine Arts. I now take my grandchildren. The new site is more problematic. Parking is terrible at the pier, and the new admission price is too high. That said, if you can afford it, the hands-on displays are wonderful. The kids love them,...


More  



This museum seems to be for children when you first walk in. We are two adults who decided to go in and were not disappointed. There are many hands on displays that were very interesting. There were a lot of children on field trips but there are so many different displays that it didn't seem crowed.
This is a great...


More  



Stumbled on to this on a long walk along the embarcadero, had not visited in years and it has recently moved to this new site, great facility for families

Used City Passes cert to get in.
It is right near the trolley cars @ Pier 15.
Our kids liked the various sections that combined fun actvities (mirrors, games) with learning. A good way to spend time for a few hours with young kids.

We had to pull our kids out of this place. There is so many hands on activities your kids will be happy for hours. Amazing views and location also.

Our company rented out The Exploratorium for an event and it was a great place to visit.
There were so many cool things to try and look at. I plan to go back again and spend more time there with my family. For me this was a "great find."

This museum is worth to visit. Very interesting for both adults and children.
Plan at least 4 hours to have time so see and experience everything.

great fun for all ages ...we especially enjoyed the movies and the interactive exhibits as well as the amazing rain forest exhibit

title: Palace of Fine Arts, San Francisco
review_list:
A beautiful memento from World Fair to the City . . . .
Revolving Expositions and ornate sculptures . . . . A nice stroll around the water with Ducks creating beautiful ripples

We have seen this place highlighted in movies and TV shows but this was our first visit to the actual site - and it was spectacular! The architecture is absolutely gorgeous and seems unreal in the middle of a city. The sun was shining and there were tons of people enjoying the surrounding park and we got some fantastic photos.

Beautiful place to walk around, nice architecture, swans and ducks. Just remember that the Exploratorium has moved to pier 19 and there is no other exhibitions except "Hungry Games". Don't forget to bring camera

After a few rainy days in San Francisco we decided we would chance the weather and go visit the palace of fine arts, definitely worth the journey across town just to sit on a bench and enjoy the sunshine in one of the most beautiful parks I have been to.

a beautiful place to photograph. large columns and stunning architecture. beautiful at night all lit up.

This is a lovely place - still used as an arts venue but lovely to chose wander around the grounds. Very picturesque.

The Palace of Fine Arts is so pretty. It is great for a leisurely stroll around on a nice day. The building are incredible, and reminiscent of Rome.
Great photo spots!

Very artificial but always beautiful. The Palace of Fine Arts is an extremely picturesque stopped in San Francisco. Amazing little lagoon with beautiful birds and fantastic old looking buildings.

My wife and daughters went to the Hunger games exhibition here. I went with and left via the marina area. It's a long walk before you get to a bus stop. The architecture of the space was amazing.

They have recently renovated this park & it is really nice to walk around under the dome & around the lake. Swans swim by & other marine birds. They have lit it up to look beautiful at night. They have a theater in the complex, & there are performances of all sorts & variety are held there. It is easily...

title: Cable Cars, San Francisco
review_list:
Took Cable Cars for a ride to shop and see the gorgeous vistas. Great tips from the conductors for places to shop and visit.

Waited in line for about 20 minutes before we eventually boarded. Bit of a frenzy to get on. An old couple who lived nearby were beside us and told us they came there to relive their youth. They refused seats when offered as they love hanging off the side. Good experience and unusual way to travel - great views of...

Make sure you always ride the cable cars. A San Francisco must see! I always walk to the wharf and take them to downtown.

no matter where you go, these cable cars are sure to pass you by, just hop on and take a wonderful ride

Even though the price has risen considerably over the years since I was a boy exploring the streets here, the ride is always a thrill with the sounds of cables running under the car when you come to a stop, the clanging of the bells and the rush of a Vibrant city.

A visit to San Francisco would NOT be complete without a ride (or 2 or more) on the various cable cars. This is a great way to people watch and get up the big hills. Fun for folks of all ages.

Your in SF you got to do it. What's more SF than a cable car ride. Don't get on at the beginning station with the long lines just walk up to the next stop and jump on there and save yourself a couple oh hours wait. Each ride is $7 pp and you can pay the person once you jump...

Yes...the trolley wait Can be Long...as this is a Very Popular 'attraction'...but we LOVE the olde wooden trolleys. Mostly a tourist thing to do when in San Francisco;
I suggest you obtain an all day or multiple day public transportation pass and make full use of public transportation and use Lyft and Uber for the rest of it!
Parking & driving is a nightmare in San Francisco and I am an experienced SF driver!

We took our two kids form the Fisherman's Wharf to Union Square. They loved it!
Take into consideration that it is not the fastest way to travel neither the most economic, a taxi could cost between 8-11 and cable car 21 for 3 people (my younger kid didn't pay).

title: California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco
address: 55 Music Concourse Drive, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94118
review_list:
We chose to come here after reading the great reviews on trip advisor however after going I really can't see what all the fuss is about. Barely any animals and not very interactive. Very very expensive for what it is. However the aquarium and planetarium were both good.

Thoroughly enjoyed visit! Very educational but also full of exciting animals and picturesque areas. Definitely would return again

We spend one morning there and went to the planetarium, the earthquake simulation, the tropical rainforest (the albino alligator was there) and walked around.
The kids loved it!

Really enjoyed the variety of exhibits but it was really hard to navigate them. There was not "start" or directional indications so walking through seemed a real hodgepodge of information. Many of the exhibits didn't have any signs explaining what there except for a title. Loved the Color of Life exhibit and the Earthquake demo was impressive. If you have...

Science is not for everyone, but it should be. In the California Academy of Sciences, scientists of all ages and level of expertise can glimpse science at its almost rawest state. From the living beings behind glass to the life size animals on display, you can see what animals are or can be. Sky's the limit for those of us...

This is a great museum. It is very expensive, even for kids. There is definitely something (or a lot of things) for everyone. The aquarium and rainforest are spectacular. The penguins and the living roof are cool. The planetarium show line was very long, so we did not see a show. The naturalist center is the best part. Ask a...

With a group of school pupils aged between 14-18, it was always going to be tricky pleasing all pupils with the activities, however, the Academy of Sciences did just this. Everyone enjoyed the 4 hour (we extended the time there) visit, taking in the aquarium, planetarium and rainforest experience. The staff were extremely helpful and interesting (most of them volunteers)....

The shows are a must!! Food is pricy- parking is 30$, if you don't mind walking 10 minutes there is unlimited parking on Stow road( in the park past the Academy- I think that's the name of the road) it's a one way road-you can bring your own food...

Academy of Science is a great place to visit, especially Thursday evenings. they usually have special night. it might be even half of. It's good idea to take advantage of it because it is pricy. It is fantastic to see butterflies to fly. don't forget to watch video in their special room. You will watch it as if you are...


More  



This is just one interesting place. There are always all sorts of things happening here, & exhibits in progress. There are things for young & old alike. There are new exhibits, & permanent ones. The Walt Disney Family Museum is a wonderful place for fans and for those who wish to know a bit more about the man, his family, and the early years of the Walt Disney Studio. Was not sure what to expect but was pleasantly surprised. You follow Walts entire life, nothing is left out. Amazing pictures, stories, sketches the list goes on. Difficult to find the museum to begin with!

Whether you are a Disney fan or just like museums, the Walt Disney Family Museum is great. Does't look like much from the outside, but it's actually very large. This is a little overlooked, very interesting with a lot to see. great amount of things to see and learn. Highly recomend

although it's called a museum don't let that deter you. This tells the story of Walt Disney, and his family and business and employees, and of course the products. Off the beaten track but worth hunting out as being a bit of a Disney fan we found this very, very interesting and spent a good few hours here and learnt a lot about good old Walt - plus the view of the Golden Gate bridge as you enter through the building was a nice little extra :-)

title: Legion of Honor, San Francisco

Art has changed throughout the ages, but what remains true is that the art people make speak to them and then to others. I am no artist, but I can feel art should it speak to me. The Legion of Honor is set on a hill in San Francisco, CA. Once there, one may see a fantastic view of the...


More  



The museum is well laid out, the temporary exhibitions are downstairs and quite good. Always a good visit.

Beautiful location with a lovely collection. Cafe offers opportunity to rest and refresh. Strongly recommend this museum.

We are museum people. We always allocate disproportionate amounts of vacation time to the museum. This place was full of beauty. Some of our favorite artists were represented, such as Fantin-Latour, and Calibotte. Also there was a rather atypical Van Gogh. We saw A Lady with a Unicorn, by Raphael. Not something you see in America every day. Wear comfortable...

On our last day in San Francisco, we visited the Legion of Honor. Despite the constantly crowded lot, someone broke into our car and stole some...

We had a great couple of hours here and could have stayed longer. It is scenically located and has a very nice collection of art of all types.

This museum has something for everyone. We love do the hike by the golf course and making our way up to the museum. You will see some of the best views of both the city and the Golden Gate bridge. So I am from the area, and have lived here for about 2 years, and usually went to the Deyoung. I had heard of the "Legion of Honor; but dismissed it. Then I was looking for somewhere to go with my 3 year old on a day off from work. Children's museum was too far away. So I came here....

The Legion of Honor has the most amazing restrooms. I recommend room 19. The art us exquisite. The periodic benches are greatly appreciated.

title: Cable Car Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
fascinating tour and explanation of the above ground and below ground operation of the famous San Francisco cable car system. Well worth visit and very user friendly with a nice little gift shop.

This museum is set at the main cable workings for the cars. You can see the wheels and cables as they activate the three different lines. Worth a stop

Small museaum dedicated to cable cars. it's also the location where they actually runn all of the cable for the working cable cars. We spent maybe 30 minutes there.

Very interesting, and lots of informative displays about not just the cable cars, but the city in general.

I enjoy this sort of thing. There is a large pit/open area where all the machinery it takes to run the cable car system resides. We have been there a couple times when they were splicing a cable. There are several complete systems, one for each line. You can go down stairs and see where the cables disappear into the...


More  



Hop on, hop off tour. Interesting to see how the cable cars evolved in San Francisco and you can see the cables running to work the cars today.

Not much to see only the workings of the cable cars and a few retired cars. Because it a working station for the cars it's very load and it's small of grease from the workings.
Go a small shop and it's free, if you are area have look but I wouldn't make a special journey to it

A unique view as to how this public transportation system works. If it wasn't free we would have paid more for it!

Don't miss this--it only takes about 15 minutes or so--but you can see how the whole cable system works underground powering the cable cars currently on the streets--the original equipment from the 1890s. Plus a nice exhibit on the history of the cable car, earthquake, etc. Nice little gift shop. And did I mention it is free?

With free admission, one must visit this gem of historical significance. To see how the trolly system was engineered and maintained is well worth a visit. Highly recommended.

title: Lombard Street, San Francisco
review_list:
We initially hiked up to Lombardo street the got brave and drove the short route. Great fun! Nice restaurants in the area. Great views!

Good opportunity for a few free photos. Nice houses on both sides of the road where the winding section is located. Close walk to Fisherman's wharf.

The street is shorter than expected, and you can't walk directly down it. And man is the hill steep. I drove down it in a rented convertible which was totally worth the experience. If you're renting a car anyways it is worth the trip

You can go to this point by an electric cable car from the centre which is a good experience. THE VIEW IS BEAUTIFUL!

To drive down or walk is amazing but I wouldn't like to live at Lombart. Way to many people everyday to make pictures or to drive through. As I said already, nice to see but that's it.

Crookedest street in the US! The intersections are always filled with tourists (myself included). What an amazing view of the city, if you can drive down even better!!

If you are planning to drive Lombard be aware you will probably be queuing for 40+minutes on a very steep hill. I would definitely recommend walking it as you get a lot more time to stand and take in the views and admire the streets beauty without the queues and crowds.

We took the cable car and jumped off at the top. We watched a few cars as they started down the hill. The looks on those peoples faces as they started down the hill...... Priceless! Amazing view of the city. Worth seeing. Another one of those things you gotta do while in SF.

Would have said the world, but found another "Lombard street" in Norway. This is a must see photo op from various angles. You used to be able to drive it (now that was no small feat), but I am told it is now off limits to anyone who doesn't live on the street. Anyway, be sure to see it.

This is an amazing street - if you can call it a street - it has not a street to move along driving down this one-way is fun and the drive is the target - not to reach the end :-)
Equally fun is to watch the other going down the hill and to see how step it is -...

(no, I didn't find out why)

Jammed with mechanical amusements of all types, it will delight youngsters and rekindle memories of the older folks.Best part: kids can touch everything.

This is for all ages,by I think the people over 40 will like it a lot more then a teen would.There is no charge to enter and walk around to look at all of the old penny arcade games,and if you want to play them you can very cool for history buffs.

Bring your quarters and spend an hour reminiscing over antique and old coin operated games. The museum is free to enter, and has an amazing collection of these devices. A fun experience.

Very cool old arcade games in working order. Some are merely dancing wooden marionettes, but my kids were still interested. Even without tickets and prizes. Came her twice to spends some quarters. Only issue is if a game doesn't work, there doesn't seem to be any employees.

title: Pier 39, San Francisco

Tons of variety of shops, street vendors, and restaurants. Churros were awesome and fresh. This is a must stop location to see the seals and sea lions. You could easily spend a couple hours here. There's also a stage with magic shows. There's a carousel too. Fun location.

Things to do
Rent a bike

Visit aquarium
Eat and drink till u drop

to see San Francisco as a different city you should go both at daytime and at night: nice restaurants, birds not scared of people< a beautiful promenade of a port.

review_list:
Although it's rather hard to get to if you don't have a car, it's worth the trip getting there. It's free, a historic fort, and has great views of the underside of the famous Golden Gate Bridge.

Learn the history of the fort that never had to fire a shot to protect the harbor. Learn of how this great site of preserved while the golden gate bridge was being build. I will bring my friends that like history on my next visit.

Not many people where in this building but it really is the best place to get a really good picture of the Golden Gate and it's pretty neat to read about what this used to be. Cool Spot

3 floors and a roof top to explore. You can look at several barrack rooms, Doctors office and best of all an ammunition room that the kids will enjoy walking through short tunnels to maneuver through. There are several cannons still on sight.

In a time when prolific best selling authors may hire a writer to turn their story outlines into full length novels, or when poorly written novels that are designed to entice solely with sex become a global phenomenon, City Lights Booksellers stands as a beacon to any avid reader with an appetite for knowledge.

A Gayborhood is a gayborhood. I appreciate the history of my people. It just makes me sad that so many of the businesses are still pharmacies, and related to the poor choices that we often make. This is not a commentary on those who have been less fortunate in some respects, it is just sad to me.

title: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, San Francisco

The park really shows the history of the shipping industry of San Francisco. With real ships you can explore it is a great place to check out!

The Wharf can be so chaotic and packed wall-to-wall with tourists that it was a very nice break to hit the museum with exhibits, looks at some of the spectacular trees, watch swimmers in late December, walk the shoreline, and explore the ships on the old pier that was used to ferry cars before the Golden Gate Bridge was built....

An thought provoking performance, an excellent piece of social science fiction, and a moving story with a superb cast.

Stage Kiss is a brilliant concept and works well on several levels, from outright slapstick and commedia del'arte style, to satire of pretentious theater and of romantic love, to compelling drama. Stage Kiss is an amusing play which was delightfully executed. The stagecraft was well thought out and it worked. This is a beautiful old theatre which is supported by a number of dedicated volunteers. This was theatre at its best. VERY WELL DONE.

title: Treasure Island, San Francisco
review_list:
Located between San Francisco and Oakland and accessible from Bay Bridge, Treasure Island provides great vantage points to view the Bay from various angles.

Great views of the city at night and the bay bridge lit up from treasure island. It also gives you and excuse to cross the very impressive bay bridge if coming from San Francisco.

A sweater or jacket is ideal because it will always be very cold here. Parking is not a problem and...

JUST seeing it, was reeling and brought me to tears, such a beautiful quite space, just nestled off the highway bridge areas, was ENOUGH for, me. It reminded me, of some of what I have gone through to begin the journeys I am on currently.

The views of San Francisco and the Bay are spectacular; however, I did not see any place where you could sit and enjoy the atmosphere. There were lots of empty parking lots full of port holes. More

Good old Treasure Island just lies there quietly in the Bay having seen it all - from being an active ship / Navy base back when to a site for large concerts & events today. It's a peaceful spot to stop in off the Bay Bridge and get the best waterfront views of San Francisco. Fun aside. ...

We drove around the island to explore and its a little sad to see how run down it is. But the view back across the bay is amazing and worth the stop!

This tiny museum is the best way to feel the beat generation and have a look at original books, pictures and keepsakes! The staff is nice, and in the bookstore you can find some gems and rare books!

This museum was everything that Jack Kerouac would want it to be, it is not too gentrified to commercialize the work of the beats, instead the museum communicates the attitudes, philosophies and works of the beat generations heroes in an engaging series of rooms and theatres that really capture the essence of the movement.

title: SS. Peter and Paul Church, San Francisco

I'm one of those people who goes into most of the impressive looking churches I see. St. Peter and St. Paul is a Catholic church with dual spires that rise 191 ft. so I first saw them from the...

We sometimes stop in to rest and relax, to sit and admire, while taking a break from wandering and eating, even though we have no connection to or interest in the religion.

Special for a church the street number is 666:)

Beautiful Gothic cathedral, stopped by for a prayer before making the steep walk up Filbert Street to Coit Tower.

We attended Mass at the church where Joe DiMaggio served as an altar boy. It is near his childhood home. It is within walking distance of Fisherman's Wharf.

I was in town for a few days on business and had to go to the post office a block away. I have been by here several times but never actually walked up to the church. It is very impressive and really stands out. The church bells are music to your ears and at night the lighting makes it regal....

Intricate and lovely. Impressive architectural design. Great appreciation, even from a non-Catholic. Definitely worth the stop if in the area.

This church is beautiful inside and out. Parts of several movies have been filed at this church including Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry and Dead Pool and parts of Sister Act 2 were also filmed here. Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe had their wedding photos taken here after a civil ceremony.

title: Balmy Alley Murals, San Francisco
address: Off 24th Street, Parallel to Treat Ave and Harrison Street between 24th & 25th Streets., San Francisco, CA 94110
review_list:

Another of San Francisco's very interesting side streets. I think it's worth going out of your way to see Balmy Alley. Some interesting colorful murals and some very interesting subject matter. Get a selfie with the San Francisco arrest scene.

Impressive murals, each conveying its own message. Some were very intricate and elaborate, but all vividly colourful.

Tip: Head over to the nearby Philz Coffee...


More  



Don't go here after the sun goes down. It's safe in the day but keep your head up. Don't drive your car down this alley, just walk.

Lots of different styles of art abound on this long strip of art that is at the back of peoples' homes and garages. Excellent colorful murals. Many by women and portraying women. Perceptive Political commentary and evocative religious imagery abound. A must see in the Mission Disrict.

Doesn't take long to experience it and is never to be forgotten.

title: St. Patrick Catholic Church, San Francisco
review_list:
After a conference, we went to St. Patrick's Catholic Church to visit and pray. The church was a true sanctuary for weary souls.

Sandwiched in and among the new and shiny of the City, Ol' St. Pat's still draws the faithful and the tourist alike. The location is set off my the surroundings, and walking inside is like walking back in time.
Enjoy!

I popped into St Patrick's during a busy Sunday afternoon and was instantly calmed by the tranquil atmosphere.
The church itself was nice enough but for anyone from Europe it wasn't particularly outstanding.

Great church in the heart of downtown. Chimes out all the calls to prayers and if you are in the Marriott it works as a great alarm clock!

Was blessed to attend a Sunday Mass and a weekday Mass here right next to our Marriott. What an inspiring priest and such a well-maintained historic Church in the heart of the city. Thank you for making it so easy to Keep The Faith!

Attended the Sunday 9:00 am mass because this church was close to Park Central hotel. Basic mass; beautiful church.

Loved the stained glass at this house of worship. The structure is classic to view. If you're a fan of old churches like myself, you'll enjoy the experience here.

I happened to joint the mass in this church. The stained glasses were beautiful and overall the church was not over decorated at all, which fits to my taste.

We attended Mass at 10:30am on a Sunday and the Mass was impressed with the beauty of the building.
The Mass was said in Latin and English (although it was not a Latin Mass which uses pre-Vatican II format).
It looked like a great community of faith that we were able to join them for a short while.

We hiked up the hill to watch the sun set and it was beautiful...from the hill you get breathtaking views of the city. Dress warm because it can get pretty windy up there.

Bernal Heights has nothing to envy to Twin Peaks. Both places offer a view of SF from a hill, but in Bernal Heights you will not find the big crowds of tourists and you will end up having the entire place to yourself. Gorgeous view just a few minutes away from the Mission!

Nice place to chill , more locals than visitors. All welcome and the views are awesome! And the $$$$ is right! It's a nice area to visit pretty cool houses and good food for all just a couple of blocks away!neighborhood and to
Free ft FREef

More  



Wonderful views of San Francisco, it's a relatively easy climb on mostly asphalt road cut off from car traffic. We had no problem finding free parking available at the base of the climb. More  



Thank goodness this area is not well known. We were on top of Bernal Hill with approx 6 other people. No traffic and free of charge. The breathtaking 360 degree views are stunning. If you are in the mood for a hike then go for it.

We hiked up here on a gorgeous sunny day and were rewarded w/ fantastic views - so - don't forget your camera. Stop in some of the fun neighborhood restaurants after your hike.

title: Women's Building Mural, San Francisco
review_list:
There are many great murals in SF, and especially in the Mission District, and this is certainly one of them.

I visited the Women’s Building to check out the murals on the afternoon of July 28th, my first day of seven in San Francisco.

I'm surprised this is not rated higher! What a beautiful building in The Mission neighborhood.

... but please, People .... They are a nonprofit. So before you go off to get your $4 coffee, please go in and make a donation. Leave something useful behind from your trip to SF.Seriously, the culture that created this mural is being destroyed by gentrification. Make a positive statement by helping.

title: Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial and Waterfall, San Francisco
review_list:
Right in the downtown area, near MOMA and the Yerba Buena, is this lovely little park. So many people on a sunny day, lounging and enjoying. The waterfall is so touching, such a legacy he left us.

View it from afar, view it from the sides, view it from behind, where you can read multi-lingual quotes from the great American civil rights leader and hero Martin Luther King. Find a favorite and read it out loud. Take photos from different angles. Also enjoy the rest of Yerba Buena and the surrounding area with so much to see...


More  



This is a beautiful waterfall designed memorial dedicated to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Located in San Francisco's eclectic Mission District.
It's super easy to find and definitely worth capturing. I enjoy seeing how different cities across the States honor Dr. King, I must say SF did me proud with this memorial.

Of all the MLK locations I've seen this by far is the best. It's such a peaceful place to visit with the waterfalls present. It's in a nice arts area and has a lot of space for people to read, relax and take in the atmosphere. Definitely a must see while in the area.

The Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial and Waterfall is located in the Yerba Buena Gardens. It is a nice waterfall, but not remarkable in any fashion. If you're in the area, as I was, it's worth stopping by to see the gardens and waterfall; however, I would not recommend going out of your way to visit this SF attraction.

We were not expecting much, but since we were in the Convention Center, we wandered over at lunch time. It's a lovely and tranquil little park and a very nice tribute to Dr. King. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to make a trip here, but, if you're in the area, it's nice.

In the heart of the city, amongst the noise and chaos, is a roaring waterfall to comemorate the life of Dr. King. Children love to run their fingers across the glass plaques etched with moving quotes by the great peacemaker written in several languages.

SF stands for many, if not most of the principles that the Rev. Dr. MLK stood for; so, an appropriate and inspiring memorial seems to be needed, as well as a very peaceful waterfall... And, it's just steps from the Museum of the African Diaspora, another must-see...

We walked by here during lunch time and there were a ton of locals enjoying the park and having lunch! The memorial itself was well done and we enjoyed all of the quotes from Martin Luther King, Jr.
Definitely worth a quick stop if you're in the area or are looking for a nice spot for a picnic!

Nice spot to walk around in the city. Big grass area for a picnic or to just relax. Lots of things to do on all sides of this memorial.

title: Stockton Street, San Francisco
review_list:
I often find myself on Stockton Street during visits to San Francisco.This long North/South thoroughfare runs between Market and Beach streets and includes a tunnel that extends for a bit more than two blocks. Buses travel the street regularly and many can be picked up near Union Square -- an upscale shopping district.

Stockton street is the main market street in the area of Chinatown, where fresh produce is sold from shops and stand all across it. Weird Chinese stores selling exotic foodstuff that doesn't have an English name and an Asian candy shop where only the brave dare - All this and more, on Stockton Street.

I stayed on Stockton Street for business and over the 4th of July weekend this year.
It's a relatively quiet street, but the entire length features a wide range of shops, restaurants and attractions. If you get time to walk it, it's fascinating.

San Fran...the city that never sleeps....not. We couldn't find a parking space until just before 6:00 pm and at 6:00 pm the vast majority of the shops closed. A few restaurants still open but it was a disappointment.

There are several shops on the street with everything you can think of. Pressed duck and prepared food, clothes, vegetables, silk komonos, lottery tickets, all sorts of fun things. It's crowded with elderly Chinese people doing their daily shopping, and the language is a sharp contrast to what the English speaker is used to.

Stockton Street takes you through the less travelled roads in Chinatown. Make a visit to this part of Chinatown as it is less touristy and far removed from the crowds elsewhere.

Stockton Street from Columbus to the tunnel is the commercial center of the real Chinatown. It is an interesting walk that you should consider doing....

title: USS San Francisco Memorial, San Francisco
address: 2400 El Camino Del Mar, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
A fitting memorial to this ship that participated in the Battle of Guadalcanal and suffered many losses. Has great vistas around it as it abuts the Lands End. Interesting incorporation of the actual ship pieces, broken though they are, as part of the perimeter of the memorial.

The story of USS San Francisco is engraved in a plaque nearby and is quite interesting. Enjoy beautiful views from here. There are park benches that look out to waves crashing against rocks that stick out of the beautiful blue Pacific with the golden gate bridge in the distance. Gorgeous!

My favorite spot to sit and enjoy the beauty. Most amazing views of the ocean and Golden Gate Bridge. Nice trails to enjoy and plenty of parking.

very nice memorial. nice setting. didn't feel scared or have problems with theft. decent stop while touring the sites.

I would advise against visiting this area, unless you are partial to vehicle burglary and theft. When I returned, I found my rental car windows broken into and some of my personal things stolen....


More  



I took the steps up from the trail to get a better view and decided to walk over and see what the memorial was about seeing I was there. I am glad I did, being Australian, I am grateful for their sacrifice seeing we were next on japans hit list. R.I.P.

Good place to go if you want to avoid the Tourist traps. Plenty of parking trails and a great view. There's a nice little restaurant nearby could get a good lunch.

The memorial is very small but humbling in the same respect. The memorial itself is built from actual pieces of the ship which was decommissioned due to the heavy damage sustained during the battle of Guadalcanal. i have used Neptune service when my uncle passed away, there are very helpful and needful in time and also the parer work was taken care peacefully and without disturbing others which was really stunning, well we all were disturbed the way they handled makes me to write this review..they are top class and simply superb.
